title: NHS chief slams MMR vaccine ‘myths’ spread among parents at school gates
text:
NHS England’s chief has issued a warning against the anti-vaxxer movement

England’s top NHS official has hit out at ‘harmful myths’ spread at school gates about the MMR vaccine.

‘Vaccine-hesitant’ parents are liable to spread dangerous fake news about the vaccine even if they are well-meaning, NHS England’s chief executive Simon Stevens warned.

Mr Stevens said health services will make it easier for parents to get their children vaccinated over the coming year but warned against ‘toxic’ pseudoscience after the World Health Organisation announced the UK is no longer measles-free.

Last week it emerged the vaccination rate for infants getting their first MMR jab has fallen for the fifth consecutive year, leaving one in ten children at risk.

Writing in the Daily Mail, Mr Stevens said: ‘Crucially, this rate is below the 95 per cent threshold where a critical mass of people is protected, creating a ‘herd immunity’ that keeps the whole population safe.’

He said the figure matters because the lives of children who cannot be vaccinated due to treatments like chemotherapy depend on other kids having had the jab to keep measles at bay.

The vaccine is not only safe but ‘essential’, he added.

‘Dropped rates of vaccination mean many more people are vulnerable and exposed to risk, and all it takes for a whole society to be in danger is for one person to catch a disease and start a contagion.’

A child receives a vaccine injection (Picture: REUTERS/Valentyn Ogirenko)

Infection risks may swell after the World Health Organisation’s report warned of Brits effectively importing illness after holidays abroad.

Earlier this week the outgoing top government health advisor, Dame Sally Davies, said England may have to introduce mandatory vaccines.

She told BBC Radio 4’s Today programme: ‘We need to up our vaccination rates.

‘I hope we can do it by other means, but if we can’t, we might well end up with mandatory.’

David Elliman, consultant community paediatrician at Great Ormond Street Hospital in London, called for vaccination clinics to be set up at events such as music festivals.

Mandatory vaccination should not be introduced to ‘prop up failures in the system’, he added.

As well as the ethical issues of forcing people to have the jab, ‘there really is no convincing evidence from anywhere that [mandatory vaccination] works’, he said, adding: ‘We could make things worse.’

The MMR vaccine has been the subject of conspiracy theories since the 1990s (Picture: AP)
